intro: Lamprocarpus, commonly known as the New Zealand flax, is a genus of flowering plants in the family Asphodelaceae. It is native to New Zealand and consists of several species, including Lamprocarpus tetrandrus and Lamprocarpus tetrazonatus. These plants are characterized by their grass-like leaves and small, clustered flowers. They typically grow in coastal and wetland environments, thriving in moist, well-drained soils. Lamprocarpus species are often used in traditional Māori practices and have ecological significance in their native habitats.
